segments.text: Hi Ajay. Hi Rohit. How is it going? It's going good. Alright, so I'm doing a small research
to understand how teenagers handle payments. So I'll ask you a few questions. Sure, sure.
Yeah, and this conversation is being recorded. Yeah, no worries, no worries. I have the consent
on it, no issues. Okay, it'll just be used for research. No worries. Got it. So to start,
can you describe your normal day in life? Yeah, it generally goes good, like getting
up in the morning, you know, getting ready to work. We'll go to work and keep on working
and sometimes we're on a break, we use some payments, like we buy something. And we'll
be like, finishing our work, get back to our places where we stay, even in travels, you
know, etc. Okay. You were telling me you work, where do you work? Like, what work do you
do? A tech-based company in a technical role. Okay. I'm working as a software intern, a
company associated in Bangalore. Yeah. So, when does money usually show up in your day?
Okay. So, initially in my day, money shows up when I board the bus. So, there I have to do a
UPI payment, which is costing around like 6 to 15 rupees. So, that is one mode of payment I use.
And secondly, sometimes in my office, I use payments to buy some snacks, like, you know,
chocolate or whatever, drinks or something. Then, and sometimes at night, when we have,
mostly it's used on food basis. Got it, got it, Ajay. So, you mentioned UPI,
which one do you use? Which app? See, like, it depends. Generally,
prior I used to use Google Pay. Now, I'm like, mostly using phone pay. And yeah, these are the
primary payments. And if sometimes offers hit, like, you know, if they get any 20-30 rupees
discount, I just go to those things, like, you know, sometimes Paytm and all.
Okay. So, why did you shift from Google to phone pay?
See, it's a general psychological perspective. Like, if we download, actually, what is the thing
is that prior I didn't have phone pay. After I downloaded this app, and I started using it,
it became the default one. It used to be like that. It's just a psychological asset
that we had started using phone pay. So, I was just going, if, like, something hits,
it will be like that. 80% I use phone pay. Maybe sometimes Google Pay and phone pay doesn't work
well. Like, you know, the servers are not responding at all.
Okay. So, why did you install Google Pay in the first place?
Okay. So, initially, like, when I was, like, you know, in my teens, like, 18s or 19s,
it was the primary app which was getting served it. Like, you know, phone pay had also had it, but
Google Pay was something like, I, according to me, I've seen many Google Pay ads. So, that
pulled me a lot towards itself. So, I just downloaded it and I started using it as a default.
Okay. So, where did you see the ads for Google Pay?
See, Google Pay was, like, not that thing. See, I used to, like, you know, there are QR codes in
the shops, like, you know, which are primarily based on Google Pay. Most of the shops in back
in COVID used to use Google Pay. Then, sometimes, even in, you know, like, cricket advertisements
and, you know, TV advertisements, these things come.
Okay. Yeah. So, if I can ask, what was the first payment app you downloaded?
Payments app? Yeah.
Might be Paytm. Yeah, it was Paytm.
Okay. And from Paytm, why did you download another app?
As I already mentioned, it's just a psychological aspect
to have, like, two to three things, right? Whatever is possible.
Like, all the modes available payment. Now, there are, like, modes, like,
you know, and there are many things. So, it gives offers, like, you know, initially.
So, generally, like, you see, if we order, like, Swiggy, if you're ordering food on Swiggy,
we see that this Bharat, it's not Bharat, actually, some particular app, it gives, like,
25 rupees discount. That attracts me to download that app. And some give 75 rupees in the initial
thing. So, maybe because of that, we get to download the app. So, that is one major.
Okay. Like, yeah.
So, although you have all these apps, PhonePe is your primary app?
Yeah, before it's PhonePe. Now, I'm using Google Pay, Paytm. I have PhonePe now. Bharat
Pay was also installed. And, yeah, like, but from, and I used to have FamPay also. Now, it's not,
I'm not using it right now.
Okay. When did you install FamPay?
When I was in my teens, actually, like, you know,
2018, back then. No, not that long. Oh, sorry, sorry. 2020. Okay, post-COVID, like, 21, 22. Yeah.
Yeah. If I may understand, like, what was your age roughly around then?
So, if I'm correct, you had used Paytm before FamPay?
Yeah, yeah. Yes, you're right.
Okay. So, what made you install FamPay?
Okay. So, Paytm was generally my, see, I wasn't a legal holder of a bank account,
because I was 16 or 15 when I started using Paytm. It was my mother's account. Okay. So,
my mother used to send me money on that. So, I used to use it. But when FamPay just said it's a
bank for teenagers, like, you know, teens, they provide a debit card. It has a limit,
like, restrictions and all, where we cannot have higher limits. It's just a bank for teenagers.
So, that attracted me using FamPay. And, yeah. So, it's, like, we have that self-account rate.
In teens, we have these aspects, right, which attracts us towards it. Yeah.
Got it. So, where did you hear about FamPay?
FamPay, you know, it comes, like, if there were little advertisements, I'm not sure, actually.
Maybe in Instagram handles only. Yeah. On Instagram handles, it used to show up. And then,
I used to have a small dig and research whether it's safe or not. And then, it was safe.
They offered a good range of, like, a debit card was also offered.
Hmm. So, you mentioned you did some research and you found it safe. Can you let me know,
like, what research you did and why did you conclude it was safe?
Basically, like, we get many links, you know, like, there are some third-party apps which ask
to install in them. They give higher credits. But most of them are, like, you know, spam or
something like fraud cases are more. So, FamPay is something like it has its own website. And
primarily on App Store or Google Store, they give reviews on that. So, it's an App Store certified
thing. And primarily, some of my teen friends also started using that app. So, yeah, that way.
Okay. So, seeing the reviews on App Store, you felt it was safe and it had a website.
No, not like that. It was, like, you know, it was assured. It was assured by some of the,
like, RBI. It had the regulations and all. It was registered with that, right? So, that was
the primary aspect. Not, like, App Store, like, to check the performance of the app,
how it helps us, like that. Got it.
So, if I'm correct, you use UPI apps on a daily basis?
Yeah, obviously. At least once in a day, for sure.
Makes sense.
It's actually replaced cash, most probably.
Makes sense. So, what is the biggest transaction you did?
This is a tricky one. Like, you know, yeah, obviously, like, somewhere between 90,000,
99,000, whatever limit was possible.
Okay. If I may know, can you tell me what did you use that for?
Yeah, why not? Like, it was used for my college fees or some of my semester fees because
it was only 1 lakh a day. So, if the fees is, like, 1,50,000 or something, I used to pay, like,
98,000 or 99,000 at one day and the other payment only another day.
Okay.
Yeah.
So, when was the last time you recommended a payment app to someone?
Maybe, not, like, somewhere near. I guess it was, like,
back in four or five years ago when my friends didn't have using these things. So,
I guess I have recommended them Google Pay. Yeah.
Okay. I know it's in the past, but if you can remember, why did you suggest them to use Google
Pay?
Yeah, like, see, the thing is that Paytm and the prior thing, it had some issues, like,
server issues sometimes. But Google Pay, I found that it was, like,
fine. And even if the payment gets stuck or something, it gives us a thing.
But in Paytm, we get to know, like, maybe 20-30 minutes late. But in Google Pay,
it gives a clear thing, like, payment is under processing or something.
Paytm gets stuck sometimes. Like, prior, not now. Now, it's fine.
Okay.
Okay. Let's go ahead in the conversation. So, let's talk about
credit cards. So, what do you know about credit cards?
I'm sorry, I didn't get it.
What do you know about credit cards?
When do I know, right?
What do you know about them? When did you get to know?
Okay, okay. See, the thing is, basically, they provide a limit, like, you know, let's assume
50,000 or something. So, we can, like, it's used for transactions where we can pay them and we
have to pay those bills later. But if we use, like, 20 or 25% of the limit, I'm not sure what

limit. Not sure of that number also, because I'm not using one now.
That's okay. Where did you learn about all this stuff about credit cards?
See, generally, we see surveys on in the delivery stations, you know, mostly these SBI agents,
State Bank of India agents are always there. So, they always, not only that, even in malls also,
we see some private banks, like, something like, not sure, but yeah, private banks where
they'll be offering their services. They'll just check the credit score on the basis. They just
tell us, like, tell me what is possible, if it is possible, what is the procedure allowed, yeah.
And me being, like, you know, like, sometimes, see, prior I was, now I'm employed, but prior I was
not employed, right? So, I had the urge, like, I could take a credit card and, you know, pay later,
which is on the pocket money which I receive. So, that if sometimes the budget of the money
gets fluctuated. So, in those cases, yeah. Okay, makes sense. So, did you not try applying for a

scooties and all, you know, like that. So, that's used for that, like, we can pay on,

to pay, like, there are, like, stores where they provide on down payments, for example,
30,000 down payment and the other 50,000 would be, like, directed in EMIs with maybe a marginal
interest of one or two percent. Okay. So, where did you get to know about this Bajaj card?
It was the ad service only, you know, they used to offer me these things,
like, the limit is possible and all. If we just click on this Bajaj app, it redirects to its

Okay. So, you didn't apply for any normal credit cards?
Apply, I guess, I've done it recently, but maybe in Kotak Mahindra Bank, but
I didn't still get a response. No, no, no, not Kotak, sorry, sorry, in SBI, maybe.
Sorry, sorry, I'm wrong. PhonePay, yeah, actually, in PhonePay app, it was providing me one thing.
So, I just submitted that application, I didn't still get a response for it, because I guess my
credit score is somewhere between four, three, eight, or four, four, four, sorry, sorry, seven,
four, zero, I guess. So, maybe because of that thing. Okay. Yeah. So, why did you decide you

you know, like, you see SnapMint, which gives a limit of 2000 initially, but based on our use,
I got a limit of 2000, but now I have a limit of like, 10, 12,000, because I pay EMI's on time.
And CredP also, see, this is only for EMI basis, SnapMint, even it provides money also, but it's
for higher interest, but coming on to CredP, it provides money on a marginal rate of interest.
Like, you know, if you're taking a loan of like, 20,000, you need to pay like, 21 or 22,000 in
return, like, in eight or nine months. So, these apps. So, I felt if a credit card is there,
I could just directly use it on things instead of these third-party apps, yeah.
That's okay. So, let's say you saw in PhonePe that you are eligible for a credit card. So,
what made you click and continue that process? Okay, I have to apply from here.
That is what I want to know. See, for mostly the thing is that PhonePe is like, one of the

So, do your friends have credit cards?
Not sure. I never clicked. This topic never came between us. Okay.
So, in the past, right, was there a time where you wish, oh, I wish I had a credit card right now,

So, do you think credit cards are scary also?
Yeah, seriously. See, like, maybe, let's assume I've done a late payment. Some banks charge too

it might be a big issue. Like, for example, I want to apply for a home loan. It plays a vital

30,000, yeah, 10 or 20,000 is fine. Not more than that. Got it, Ajay.
Yeah. So, in a credit card, what are the kind of benefits you expect that would attract you?
